segments.text: That was a real exciting time, and a time to see how a lot of decisions are brought together with a consensus.
You see where certain individuals have an influence, but in the long term it was a positive influence.
because it was the right thing for us to do and it was something that I think brought a later cooperation and support from some of the political people to help this university move forward.
And no scars.
And no scars.
No political public scars at all.
Virtually none.
You know I got a few letters.
Oh yeah.
from alumni that just were so loyal to the old Southwest Conference, but it was dead.
It was gone, and we were riding a horse that was lame and was going to become a dead horse, quite honestly.
When you walked in as the chief executive officer of the institution, what were the important matters that you had to take up right then?
Well, the first one was clearly to finish up the investigation of the NCAA issue.
The second one was to keep the momentum going in two areas.
One was the academic priorities that we had put in place.
And the second one was the endowment campaign.
We had a lot of major requests out.
And the goal was $500 million.
It wound up successfully afterwards at more than $600 million.
So it was to not let that momentum get restricted in any way and to keep that ball rolling.
On that one?
I had one other one.
Wait, wait, wait.
On that campaign, does John Lindsay deserve a pat on the back?
Absolutely.
John Lindsay got a great pat on the back, and so did Bill Lone Star Gaze.
I don't know.
Oh, man.
We'll think of it later.
I'll come up with his name.
Anyway, they deserved a tremendous pat on the back.
As well as did Eddie Joe Davis, who was president of the foundation.
And I traveled this state that year speaking to former students groups and telling them what we were doing.
And it's real encouraging when you go share and you talk about the Aggie tradition, the Aggie family, the Aggie students.
the Aggie Honor Code, and when you finish they give you a standing ovation.
And you meet so many wonderful people that believe in what we're doing.
Describe the working relationship as you saw it in action between the foundation and the institution.
That was a very strong relationship because
And I don't know a whole lot of the history prior to the time that Bill Mobley was president and then Chancellor and Eddie Joe Davis was the president.
But the two of them had worked together in the Chancellor's office to the point that a partnership was already there.
I do think that they built probably a stronger, closer relationship than had been there ever before.

And what we did that really made a difference was that we put development officers in all of the colleges, and I even put one in the provost office, so that we could get a lot of scholarship money, that we could bring in programs that would help strengthen the undergraduate programs, would help recruitment of top quality students to this university.
And I put one over in the student service side.

because great opportunities for John Colas and later Maylyn Sutherland to build up those areas that we weren't going to get additional state funding and the only way that we could continue to have excellence was to bring in outside money.
You started to add another item a while ago and I interrupted you.
Other things that were
on the table that you needed to deal with?
One other major thing that was on the table was the requirement for multicultural courses.
And I put a lot of study into that and determined that the agenda that was put forth was not
a lot of the agenda that some people had in mind, and I vetoed it.
And it created one big furor.

I had to go meet an executive session with the faculty senate, and they could not believe that a president of the university had vetoed an academic faculty decision in the hundred and almost twenty year history of the university.
I made the statement, well, they may not have before, but one has now.
And I tried to give them my reasons.
I doubt that they were all accepted.
I had one or two other groups that I had worked so hard with to increase the minority students, the minority faculty.
They wanted me to explain my reasoning why.
And I think they accepted it right and well.
I spent a lot of time going out into high schools across the state, both as senior vice president students.
But that was something on my plate.
I probably got 500 letters of support to any one letter
that was negative about it.

Those were probably the major issues that were on my plate with the exception of the kinds of things that resulted after an anonymous letter was sent to the Dallas Morning News about suspicion of improprieties in certain areas of the
there are questions about they did it was a board they did not think it was my responsibility but it was laid on my lap an issue I had to handle because there were
procedures in the whole university business operation of the approval of those that was using the wrong terminology.
And I promise you there was never any mal-intent.
There was never, as far as I could determine, ever misuse of any funds for the purchase.
But the codes and the titling of what was put on there was clearly wrong.
So I had to deal with that.
I inherited these things I'm telling you about.
There were accusations that the contract of the bookstore with Barnes and Noble was not done properly.
There were accusations that there were problems in the food service department and people had been dismissed for wrong reasons.
I had a chemistry professor that was trying to make gold out of mercury.
And they said, well, he got a gift that shouldn't have been given.
Well, there was no way of knowing that on the front end of that gift.
And the guy was later gotten in trouble with the FBI.
But how were we to know any of that part?
So, you know, I had a lot of those things laid on my table that
It took up a tremendous amount of time just to straighten them out.
Did any regent attempt to give you, as you began, attempt to give you direction, personal direction?
I would not say that any regent tried to give me personal direction, but it was not probably uncommon for a regent to call me with a
an issue that they wanted to see addressed.
And I think that has happened for many, many years.
Right.
Don't name the region.
Give some examples of the kinds of things you...
Some, you know, they would get a complaint about something happening in a classroom or with a student.
some of those kinds of things.
Did they ever want anyone terminated?
No, I never had that.
Did you get any memorable phone calls in the middle of the night about anything?
I got very few for probably one reason.
I had an unlisted number and I did that just simply so I could get rest and sleep at night.
You know, I would get a few where
There was a major issue with a student, a tragedy, for instance, a student got killed.
And I'm trying to recall, when you serve in three consecutive roles, sometimes you're not sure which role you were in when something came up.
We had some instances in the Corps, and I would get those kinds of calls from one of the vice presidents or something.
I'll tell you one of the most interesting calls I ever got was at the Cotton Boat.
And it was from Malin Sutherland, who I had named as Vice President for Student Affairs.
And Malin called me and he said, Reveille's been stolen.
And I said, you gotta be kidding me.
And here we are.
right in the middle of all this Cotton Bowl celebration, and the next day is the march in with Reveille, and Reveille's been stolen.
And we think it's by University of Texas students.
That was a late night call.
And so we began to work through all of that, and before game time, we had Reveille back.
Had Reveille been stolen?
Absolutely.
She'd been stolen from the backyard of the young man in Dallas who kept her.
And this was when she was a pup.
And what had happened was the Dallas Morning News had a beautiful article when the new Reveille was chosen.
The young man that was responsible for Revel, he lived in Dallas.
And being Dallas, well, they made a nice article out of it and how he would be in charge of it.
Well, some UT students apparently knew where he lived.
went and stole Reveille.
And they never let Reveille out of their sight except that morning they opened the door, let Reveille go into the fenced backyard with a high fence to go to the bathroom.
And apparently that student must have already been hiding in the dark in the yard and stole Reveille.
And I was on the phone to the president at UT
And he was willing to get the bottom of it, because there'd be egg on their face.
And he was so cooperative.
This is Berdahl, who is now, I believe, president at Stanford.
And he was so cooperative.
And we got to the bottom of it before the game time.
And you inherited a staff in the president's office.
Yes, I inherited a staff in the president's office.
with the exception of
the administrative assistant to the president, and I had taken and I took with me my assistant from the provost office.
Who's that?
Sandy Crawford, and she is still there to this day.
Okay, yes.
And your office was located physically, President's office.
In Rudder.
In Rudder.
Eighth floor.
On the eighth floor where it is now.
What are the advantages and disadvantages of that location?
The advantages, most of all, is that it is right in the heart and center of campus.
And you see everything around you.
And you look out over the mall, you see all the students.
But also, it's so convenient to the president's home, to the parking, and to the MSC, and to the board quarters, or the Board of Regents facilities.
And it's central.
to wherever else you might go on campus.
The central location's a great advantage.
Image-wise, it might have been better for it to have been in the administration building, that beautiful old chancellor's office that I had when I was provost, but image-wise for the students,
it's better to be in the heart of the campus where it was.
If you were going to have a small luncheon for a few people, where did you have it?
Almost always in the Memorial Student Center.
Or if it were during the day, usually in the Memorial Student Center.
Sometimes
I guess at least half of them though would be in the Alumni Center, in the Clayton Williams Alumni Center.
And then if it were night, probably the President's Hall.
We probably had more dinners at night that were smaller in size at the Alumni Center.
Did you use the faculty club much?
Yes, I did.
I used the faculty club a good bit.
for fairly small groups, and I forgot to mention that one.
And I had a lot of real small luncheons there where I'd have a small group in because it's so convenient to just go to the faculty club.
Plus, that is a great place to recruit when you can show them the entire campus by walking around.
As a sidelight, I was on the committee to plan the rudder expansion and all that, and one of the questions that we as the committee

threw at the architect over and over and over again and got overruled by people in building construction over and over, we were saying why in the world put the facility in the middle of that floor, why not put it off at one side and have where you could have maybe 200 people up there, make it where it could be divided and we got overruled over and over.
Yeah, because you can't see
in any one of those sides, a very large group at all.
When did they start the search for the presidency on a permanent basis?
Probably no later than October of 93.
And was it, by the current standards, a normal search, meaning an advertisement and a committee?
Yes, it was a completely normal nationwide search.
Okay.
And what was your desire?
Well, I allowed myself.
I knew I would be nominated.
A lot of faculty and a lot of administrators even wanted the name interim probably taken off, but I allowed my name to go forward.

But my wife and I were giving deep thought as to whether or not after that many years at that kind of pace and level and just the issues that we were having to face and to clean up, whether we really wanted to make a long-term commitment to it.
And when it got past the interview process, we both decided that we wanted some time
back together for our family and for us.
And I notified the chairman of the committee that I was withdrawing.
That was a tough decision.
In many ways my heart wanted to continue to do it.
But in another way, I felt like it might also be an appropriate time for an outside person
because of a lot of the issues that I had had to work so hard to resolve.
And I'm talking about the alcohol, food service, the NCAA, all of those.
I could go on, there's a long list of them.
There was another issue of a co-generation contract, and all of those kinds of things that someone,
with no history of being here could step into.
And I felt, I think, blessed at the end that I was able to resolve every one of those before I left so that I wasn't going to leave a lot of that for someone else.
And I wondered, you know, what am I going to do?
And there was an opportunity.
that really was down my line of interest to go to the College of Business and become the director of the Center for Executive Development and teach an honors course in leadership.
And although I could look back and say my discipline had been veterinary medicine, my true discipline had always been leadership.
That's where my heart had always been.
So, I really got excited about that being a possibility and that's what happened when we stepped out in 94.
Alright, and so you told them that you would not be considered anymore at about what point?
That was probably in March or April of 94.
I indicated to them that I was withdrawing.
and that I would support whomever they selected and would help that individual as much as I could.
And the eventual choice was Ray Bowen?
Correct.
And as far as you know, was that the committee's recommendation?
As far as I know, he was the committee's recommendation.
And he was then the interim president at Oklahoma State.
At Oklahoma State.
Did he communicate with you soon after he was selected?
Yes.
And before he came, too, I sat down and wrote out everything I could think of that was on the table, that was unresolved, and sat down with him.
when he first got here and went over everything I could think of.
I don't recall if he ever asked me for any advice, but I could not help remember what Bill Mobley told me.
I asked Bill, I said,
what advice would you give me stepping into this role as leading this university?
He said, communicate, communicate, communicate.
And had Ray asked me, and he may have, I don't recall, I would probably have said the same thing.
How important do you think it was and is for a Texas A&M former student to be the chief executive officer of this institution?
Well, it's a great asset because you come with such an understanding and just a knowledge of all of the traditions and what a special place this is.
Clearly, I think Jack Williams and Bill Mobley demonstrate that you don't have to be an Aggie to be a president here.
That very quickly becomes an Aggie, but it puts you ahead of the learning curve to understand the values, the traditions, to understand the former students.
And it clearly is an asset.
There is no question about it.
Now what topics have we not talked about in your campus-wide leadership months and years?
You were at the campus level how from?
From 89, actually the end of 88 to 94.
So six years.
Six years.
I don't know, if you were to ask me what the most enjoyable times were, to me it would clearly be the interaction with students, former students, and the Mother's Club.
Those were times where I could get to go and, quite frankly, tout, brag about the university.
and to tell them what was happening and where we were going and what our vision was of where A&M was going.
And you could see their enthusiasm, their excitement to know that here A&M was now the third largest university in the nation.
It was one of a select designated few that was land grant, sea grant, and space grant.
And I would tell them, to me that meant another obligation.
that we were a public grant, a student grant, and a parent grant.

Well, when I meshed those together with it, they could just grasp that and know that our heart was trying to maintain the value systems and the traditions of this university, and at the same time put in place the academic enhancements and programs that would elevate us
to a national level that they would be proud to see us achieve and what part they could play in it.
So those were, those were terrifically exciting times and I probably missed that more than any other thing.
They were tiring, you know, when you go get on an airplane after work at six o'clock and fly to Tyler, Texas and speak and get back about midnight that night.
It was a part of it, and I must tell you, I poured my heart and soul into it and gave 80, 90 hours a week to it.
Any scary moments on those flights?
Oh, man, did we have a scary one.
We had gone to the opening of the new outreach center in Corpus Christi, and this was for the recruitment of students to Texas A&M.
And on that plane was a young lady

In the outreach office here, that was her first plane ride, and we were coming back on the University Airplane, and we got just this side of Caldwell, and there was a horrendous thunderstorm just, I guess, west of Easterwood, and the pilot thought on radar, and we were looking at the radar, that we could see a window through it.
So he started through that window and we got sideways.
And in fact, when we got sideways, he turned around and he said, you better tighten your seat belts.
This is going to be rough.
And he could not get through it.
So he circled back and tried it one more time.
And again, we got sideways.
We flew to Austin, sat down at the state pooling board airport.
for four hours to let that blow through before we ever got back.
But that was a scary plane ride.
What about celebrities that you met or dealt with during those six years?
Oh, golly, there were a number.
Chuck Norris from TV fame was here.
He sat in the

the presidents, Box, Linda Ellerby, you know, probably the ones that I have the greatest respect for would be George and Barbara Bush because they were so humble and just down to earth people and I will never forget how funny she could be.
And we were over in the Board of Regents quarters with a reception for them one evening before a football weekend.
And the Board of Regents and MSC quarters have always been known as having great air conditioning.
And I must admit, it was cool in there.
But you turn it down pretty cool because you get all the people in there.
Bill's up.
She was there.
And it was pretty cold that night, and she comes up to me, and I was provost at the time, and she says, I want to ask you something.
And I said, yes, ma'am.
She said, is a provost supposed to save money for the university?
And I said, yes, ma'am, every chance I can get.
She said, well, why don't you go tell them to turn the air conditioning up?
And that was just her way.
Let's see, any sessions with the governor, one-on-one or almost one-on-one?
Yeah, I had a number of sessions with Ann Richards, who was the governor at the time.
And she had us being the leadership of the university over to the mansion for a dinner one night.
And that was a one-on-one.
And then we had, as I recall, two or three separate meetings just one-on-one with certain kinds of issues that we were facing.
I'll tell you, another one is when we were trying to get
appropriations through the highway department to widen George Bush Boulevard.
I went with a group of business leaders from the community and we met with her asking her if she would help us
with funds that were already into the Highway Department to get it allocated to be able to forlain it because we were now going to get the George Bush Library.
And she came along with it.
Did you get any impression of how she felt about A&M in general?
I think she had respect for A&M, but probably the conservative
nature and voting record of this university more toward Republican, her greater loyalty would probably have been to the University of Texas.
But she was always very respectful and I think had a great deal of admiration for this university.
She gave a commencement address, so we were with her at that time.
In fact, when you're senior vice president and provost, one of your responsibilities at commencement is to entertain the speaker after the speaker has spoken and all the students are going across.
So I spent a good bit of time in conversation when she spoke.
That brings up another thing that happened when I was
Senior Vice President, Provost.
We always, those of us on stage, got into the Letterman's Lounge in G. Raleigh White about 10 minutes before the procession.
And this was on a Saturday morning and we didn't have a meal beforehand.
So we just came directly from home to G. Raleigh White.
And I got there.
about 10 minutes till 9 when we were to robe and proceed in.
And I walk in, and everybody looks at me.
And they point at me, and Bill Mobley says, the speaker for commencement this morning is fogged in in Austin.
You're on.
Well, you can imagine what I thought.
And I had given a lot of speeches.
I thought, what in the world am I going to do?
So I said, okay.
I said, but I need to run to my office, which was over on the administration building, way across campus, and be able to go in and get an old speech, and maybe I can write it.
